organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Kachemak Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve

hoursOfService.gco:CharacterString: Monday through Friday, 0900 to 1700 Alaska Time

metadataStandardName.gco:CharacterString: ISO 19139 Geographic Information - Metadata - Implementation Specification

organisationName.gco:CharacterString: Kachemak Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve

abstract.gco:CharacterString: This shapefile represents one part of a complete intertidal habitat map of Kachemak Bay (the other part being a map of salt marsh plant communities). The shoreline of Kachemak Bay, Alaska, was divided into over 4200 unique physically homogeneous segments, and each segment was visited in the field. At each segment, data was taken on physical aspects of the habitat, both for the segment as a whole (such as orientation, rock type, amount of debris) and within four tidal zones (such as slope, particle size, human use, and the presence of key biological species). Photos were taken of each segment, as well as photos showing the particle size within each zone. This project was begun by Dr. Carl Schoch, and completed under the direction of Dr. Scott Pegau.

purpose.gco:CharacterString: This shapefile, along with another representing salt marsh plant communities, makes up a complete map of the intertidal habitat of Kachemak Bay, Alaska. This information can be used to understand and predict the occurrence and habitat use of a variety of intertidal organisms. The information can also be used to prioritize habitats needing protection in the event of an oil spill or other environmental contamination. Additionally, it will serve as a basemap for change detection projects in the future.

description.gco:CharacterString: URL to page containing downloads for this dataset.

mediumNote.gco:CharacterString: Compatible with: Microsoft Windows 7 ESRI ArcGIS 10.2

measureDescription.gco:CharacterString: Basic checks were performed to ensure integrity and consistency. No errors were found during review.

These data are dependent on the research and observations of scientists and reflect our current state of knowledge. Each segment with accompanying data was visited in the field between 2002 and 2004. Physical and biological conditions mapped are therefore specific to that time period, and conditions may have changed since then (especially in areas with soft sediment). Segments missing all data were never visited in the field. Areas along the shoreline with no segments have either not been mapped, or are part of a separate salt-marsh mapping project. Some segments are missing data in one or more fields, or missing photos. In this case, we neglected to collect relevant information or photos during field mapping. A few segments have photos, but not other data.

During field visits, data obtained were generally categorical, and based on visual estimates (after training field personnel with measured examples). Some variables were more accurately estimated than others. Please see final report for Gulf Ecosystem Monitoring and Research Project G040556 (Pegau, 2005) for more information on accuracy of individual parameters and detailed descriptions of those parameters. Beach orientation was measured using hand-held compasses, and grain sizes were categorized accurately by placing a gridded quadrat on the sediment. Conditions may vary somewhat across the length and width of a segment.

Horizontal position accuracy is very high. The initial segment boundaries were as accurate as the underlying data (USGS orthophotos), and position was checked in the field using hand-held GPS units to be sure data collected were associated with the correct segment. The error in hand-held GPS units was less than the half the length of a segment, assuring that we were in the correct segment when standing near the center (this could also be confirmed visually by looking at orthophotos carried with us in the field).
Dataset does not incorporate a vertical component.

description.gco:CharacterString: Extreme high and low tide lines were digitized on-screen over USGS orthophotos (1996, 1-meter resolution). While high tide lines were generally easily discernible, low-tide lines were estimated, since the underlying photography was not tidally controlled (but see Pegau 2005, for more details on tide line accuracy). Segment breaks were then created that defined a segment as a homogeneous stretch of shoreline (where major parameters measured do not change along the length of a segment). These lines were finally converted to polygons representing each segment. Each segment was visited in the field and data were recorded on paper data sheets. Data were later entered into an MS Access database (and error checked), before being exported to tabular data that were then imported into ArcGIS and added to the attribute table of the shapefile.
USGS Orthophotos, 1996 image acquisition, 1-meter pixel resolution, monochrome.
